questions.text: In the OG procedure room, a senior resident was inserting the given intrauterine copper device to a patient. The patient asks for the effectiveness of this device after the procedure. It is effective upto___
questions.solution:
The image shows a copper IUD (Paragard). Copper IUD is effective as a contraceptive for up to 10 years. 

Mechanism of action copper IUD - It causes an inflammatory reaction within the endometrium that impairs sperm viability, motility, and fertilization.

questions.text: A first-standard child was referred for evaluation of suspected autism. According to his parents, he has trouble with social interactions and also has certain abnormal repetitive behaviors. He does not have any language deficits or intellectual disabilities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pervasive developmental disorder, not otherwise specified

questions.solution:
In Asperger's disorder, there are no significant delays in language or cognitive development.

Features of Asperger's disorder:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development:
    • Markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • Failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level.
  • They do not manifest with mental retardation.
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behavior.
  • No significant delay in language.

questions.text: What does the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows Barlow's test.

It is done to test for DDH. The infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90 degrees of flexion.

The thigh is grasped and the hip is slowly adducted to 45 degrees while applying downward and lateral pressure.

This test is positive when the joint is dislocatable and a clunk is heard.

Ortolani's test indicates the reduction of the dislocated hip.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to extremely aggressive behaviour towards his family. His family members also say that he has become forgetful and has developed urinary incontinence. Which of the following lobes is likely to be involved in his disease process?
questions.solution:
Antisocial behavior, urinary incontinence, and impaired memory in this patient are suggestive of frontal lobe involvement.

Features of frontal lobe lesions:

  • Disinhibition
  • Lack of initiative
  • Antisocial behavior
  • Impaired memory
  • Incontinence
  • Grasp reflexes
  • Anosmia.

questions.text: Which among the following findings is a feature of ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Pseudopolyps are seen in ulcerative colitis. They are formed due to alternating inflammation and regeneration of the ulcerated mucosal epithelium in ulcerative colitis.

Other gross findings in ulcerative colitis include-

  • Continuous mucosal inflammation of the colon most commonly involving the rectum
  • Fine mucosal granularity
  • Collar button ulcers

All the other options are features of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A G3P2 woman started to bleed profusely after expulsion of the placenta.  In spite of medical management, she was bleeding profusely.  The obstetrician used the instrument given in the picture as a mechanical method to control PPH.  Identify________
questions.solution:
The diagram given above depicts a Bakri balloon.  When medical management fails to control PPH, mechanical methods can be tried. 

  • A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity.

questions.text: The test shown in the picture is taken in ______

choices.text: Estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle
Can be taken in any phase of menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
The image shows characterstic pattern of estrogenic phase of menstrual cycle.

A specimen of cervical mucus obtained using a platinum loop or pipette is spread on a clean glass slide and allowed to dry. When viewed under microscope, it shows, during the estrogenic phase, a characteristic pattern of fern formation. This ferning disappears after ovulation.

questions.text: A 19 year-old man presented with progressive swelling of lower end of femur. X ray shows codman triangle and CT scan of the chest reveals osteoblastic metastases. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case is osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. Distal femur, proximal tibia and proximal humerus are the common sites.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of the spread of gonococci to the tubes in pelvic inflammatory disease is mucosal.

Gonococci ascend to the tubes mainly through mucosal continuity. This is facilitated by sexually transmitted vectors such as sperms and Trichomonas.

The mucous membranes of the fallopian tubes are affected first. They become edematous and are infiltrated with leukocytes and plasma cells. Another route of spread is through the reflux of mucosal blood.

Option A: Hematogenous spread is seen in genital tuberculosis.

Option B: Lymphatics are involved in the spread of secondary organisms and in PID following post-abortal and puerperal infection.

Option C: Parametrium facilitates the spread of Mycoplasma. The gut flora can directly spread to tubes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the following is not included in this condition?
questions.solution:
Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, typically causing:

  • Endometritis
  • Salpingitis
  • Oophoritis
  • Peritonitis

Cervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections. Cervicitis itself does not have serious long-term complications if treated early and not allowed to progress to PID. It can spread upwards resulting in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) which can cause fertility problems if left untreated.

The minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are:

Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following:

  • Uterine tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as _______.
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism because the most common enzyme deficiency in CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Female pseudohermaphrodite is genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia looks like that of a male.

Note:

  • Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.
  • The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Pseudohermaphroditism of the female child is most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures.
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in the neonatal period and infancy.

These seizures are often multifocal clonic, usually start during the first few hours of life. It involves a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene causing deficiency an enzyme involved in the degradation of I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT abdomen of a 50-year-old woman shows the following finding. Which of the following classifications would you use to assess the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a simple renal cyst. The Bosniak classification system is used for the classification of renal cystic masses based on characteristics seen on contrast-enhanced CT. It is helpful in predicting malignancy risk and formulating a management plan.

Class Appearance Malignancy Management

Minimally complex: 

Size <1 mm with septa and thin calcifications

Minimally complex:

Size >3 cm with increased number of septa

Minimally thickened with nodular or thick calcifications

Bosniak 3

Indeterminate:

Complicated cysts having thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification or solid non-enhancing areas

Appears hyperdense on CT

Option A: Jackson staging is used in carcinoma penis.

Option C: Durie Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma.

Option D: Todani classification is used in cases of choledochal cysts.

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese woman underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and the specimen of gallstones removed is given below. Which of the following is least likely to be a risk factor for the formation of this type of gallstone in her?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis is not a risk factor for the formation of cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis leads to the production of black pigment stones.

Obesity, high-caloric diets, prolonged fasting, certain medications (e.g., oral contraceptives), and resection of the terminal ileum result in increased secretion of cholesterol and supersaturation of bile. This enhances the lithogenicity of bile.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Hydralazine, a vasodilator is associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus.

It is an autoimmune condition caused due to exposure to certain medications. It completely resolves after the causative drug is discontinued. Important drugs associated with this condition are:

  • Hydralazine
  • Isoniazid
  • Infliximab
  • Procainamide
  • Propylthiouracil

The important class of drugs which can cause drug-induced lupus are angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, thiazide diuretics, and TNF-alpha antagonists.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to diarrhea for 3 days. He is tachypneic on examination. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
pH 7.2
pCO2 20 mmHg
HCO3 7 mEq/L
Cl 120 mEq/L
Na 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. Normal pH is 7.35-7.45

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L( normal = 22-28)  together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate(i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mm Hg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L

Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhoea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate rich-fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is more than 12 mEq/L. The mnemonic MUDPILES is commonly used to remember the causes of increased anion gap metabolic acidosis.

M — Methanol, U — Uremia, D — Diabetic ketoacidosis, P — Paracetamol, Propylene glycol I — Infection, Iron, Isoniazid, L — Lactic acidosis, E — Ethylene glycol, S — Salicylates  

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely associated with the condition seen in this CT image of a 32-year-old male?
questions.solution:
Berry aneurysm is commonly associated with polycystic kidney disease. The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the age of the patient is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with adult polycystic kidney disease (PKD).

The prevalence of intracranial aneurysms in patients with PKD is 40%. Screening cerebral angiography is strongly considered in all patients with PKD and a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A poor diet history (rice water) and a swollen belly are suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by oedema and apathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reversible bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic gastric banding and intra-gastric balloon placement surgeries are considered to be reversible bariatric surgeries.

It is because the gastric band or the intragastric balloon can be removed once the desired weight loss or metabolic benefit is achieved.

An inflatable band is placed just below the GE junction 
↓
A small virtual stomach pouch is created 
↓
Reduces hunger (probably vagally mediated)
↓ 
Reduced consumption of food
↓ 
Weight loss

Complications of LAGB include:

  • Prolapse / Slippage (most common)
  • Band erosion of the stomach wall and rupture
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (highest risk within 1 month of surgery), managed with early ambulation, pressure stockings and LMWH.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Cusco’s speculum.

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualisation of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.

Sims' speculum is used for the assessment of rectocele and cystocele. The speculum is applied against the vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears, indicating cystocele or rectocele.  It can also be used for visualization of the vaginal walls.

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor. 

A surgeon uses a lubricated proctoscope to visualize lesions in the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum. It is done as an OPD procedure to detect hemorrhoids, polyps, or ulcers

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Choose the correct option with respect to Caplan’s syndrome.
questions.solution:
Caplan's syndrome also called rheumatoid pneumoconiosis, is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis.

It manifests as pneumoconiotic nodules along with features of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis. Caplan syndrome was first described in coal miners and later in patients with silicosis too.

Option C: Hilar adenopathy, polyarthritis, and erythema nodosum are characteristic of Lofgren syndrome.

Option D: Arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis are characteristic of Reiter syndrome.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her HbA1c level is 11.1%. What is the initial drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Insulin is the best initial drug of choice when HbA1c is > 9% at diagnosis. 

Insulin is used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes in the following cases:

  • Inadequate glycemic control with 2 or more oral agents
  • HbA1c > 9% at diagnosis

In patients with HbA1c < 9%, metformin is the drug of choice.

questions.text: Identify the logo given below.

choices.text: Ministry of Woman and Child Development
National Commission for Protection of Child Rights

questions.solution:
The given logo is of ICDS - Integrated child development services.

Integrated child development services:

It was launched on the 2nd of October, 1975, and focuses on early childhood care and development. The scheme helps in providing pre-school non-formal education and breaking the vicious cycle of malnutrition, morbidity, reduced learning capacity and mortality. Beneficiaries under the Scheme include children in the age group of 0-6 years, pregnant women and lactating mothers.

Objectives:

  • to improve the nutritional and health status of children in the age-group 0-6 years
  • to lay the foundation for proper psychological, physical and social development of the child
  • to reduce the incidence of mortality, morbidity, malnutrition and school dropout
  • to achieve effective co-ordination of policy and implementation amongst the various departments to promote child development
  • to enhance the capability of the mother to look after the normal health and nutritional needs of the child through proper nutrition and health education.

Other options:

Option B- Ministry of Woman and Child Development:

 

Option C- National Commission for Protection of Child Rights:

 

Option D- Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram is a part of the National Health Mission:

questions.text: A patient’s ABG was consistent with the curve X in the nomogram given below. His serum electrolytes were Na: 138 mEq/L, Cl: 121 mEq/L and HCO3-: 08 mEq/L. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario shows a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, characteristic of RTA (renal tubular acidosis).

This patient has a pH of 7.25 suggestive of acidosis. The bicarbonate levels are low suggestive of metabolic cause. The pCO2 is reduced(10) suggestive of respiratory compensation. All the above factors point to a diagnosis of metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. 

The normal anion gap ranges from 6 to 12 mmol/L, with an average of 10 mmol/L. The anion gap in this patient can be calculated as

Na+ – (Cl- + HCO3-) = 138– (121+9) = 138 - 129 = 9.

This means the patient is having normal anion gap acidosis. Among the given options, only renal tubular acidosis is associated with normal anion gap. All of the other options cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with jaundice and loose stools. The MRCP image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above MRCP shows multiple areas of intrahepatic narrowing with alternating areas of normal and dilated segments of bile ducts (beading) typical of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intra and extra-hepatic biliary tree. It is a progressive condition that leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis.

The common age group of primary sclerosing cholangitis is 30-45 years. Men are affected twice as commonly as women. 2/3 of these cases are associated with ulcerative colitis. It is also associated with Riedel’s thyroiditis and retroperitoneal fibrosis. 10–20% of patients develop cholangiocarcinoma. Clinical features of a patient with PSC include:

  • Intermittent jaundice
  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Pruritus
  • Abdominal pain

Liver function tests show a cholestatic pattern with an elevation of ALP and GGT and smaller rises in the aminotransferases. Bilirubin values may be variable.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intra- and extra-hepatic biliary tree.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management involving resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with decreased hearing. The skull radiograph shows the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and cotton wool skull appearance on radiograph are suggestive of Paget's disease.

Increased bone formation in Paget's disease may lead to the narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This causes compression of the cranial nerves which may lead to deafness, as seen in this patient.

Deafness due to the narrowing of cranial nerve foramina is also seen in osteopetrosis. It can be differentiated from Paget's disease by the absence of lytic lesions of the bone.

questions.text: A patient presents for her first antenatal visit after performing a home pregnancy test and gives a LMP of about 8 weeks ago. She says she is not entirely sure of her dates, however because she has a long history of irregular menses. Which of the following is the most accurate way of dating the pregnancy?

choices.text: Determination of uterine size on pelvic examination
Crown Rump Length on transabdominal or transvaginal USG
Determination of progesterone level along with serum hCG level

questions.solution: The crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate biometric predictor of gestational age. If carefully performed it has a variance of only 3 to 5 days.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the birth rate start declining?
questions.solution: The birth rate starts declinign in stage 3, the late expanding phase of the demographic cycle.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady presented with painless lumps in the right breast. On examination, two lumps of size 6 x 2 cm and 4 x 1 cm were palpated in the upper outer quadrant. Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were felt. On evaluation, there was no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging of this tumor?
questions.solution:
TNM staging of the tumor is T3 N1 M0.

In the given scenario:

  • The bigger lump is 6 cm in size - T3
  • Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes - N1 
  • No distant metastasis - M0. 

In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm). If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump. If lumps are present in bilateral breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps.

Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)

  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling in the neck as given in the image. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is a congenital sequestration of lymphatic channel
Sclerotherapy is not used in treatment

questions.solution:
The given image depicts a lymphangioma, also known as cystic hygroma. They are brilliantly transilluminant.

Lymphangiomas are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system. They are the isolated cystic mass of lymphatic tissue that has the ability to produce lymph. Over time the tumor enlarges due to the accumulation of lymph within the cyst.

Types of lymphangiomas: 

  • Simple or capillary lymphangioma: They occur subcutaneously in the head, neck, and axilla. They may also occur within the internal organs and connective tissues in the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
  • Cavernous lymphangioma or cystic hygroma: They also occur in the neck or axilla. Rarely they may occur in retroperitoneum.

Treatment includes surgical excision of the tumor and image-guided sclerotherapy.

If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions.

Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: The anesthesia PG applies a cream with an occlusive dressing on the forearm of a baby brought for IV cannulation.  1 hour later, the baby allows him to place the cannula without crying. What is the composition of the cream that was applied?
questions.solution:
The substance applied by the anesthesia resident is EMLA cream (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetic) which consists of a 1:1 mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine.

A eutectic mixture has a melting point lesser than the individual drugs and hence the mixture is in the oil form at room temperature.

EMLA can provide adequate dermal analgesia for procedures like:

  • Split skin graft harvesting and laser skin treatments
  • Venipuncture and intravenous cannulation in children
  • Lithotripsy
  • Circumcision

EMLA is applied 45-60 minutes before the procedure with an occlusive dressing as shown in the image. It provides analgesia up to a depth of 5mm which lasts for 1-2 hours.

EMLA cream should not be used on mucous membranes, broken skin, infants younger than 1 month of age, or patients with a predisposition to methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Bubonocele is a type of _________.
questions.solution:
Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal.

Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of the processus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetal development.

Related Pearl: Types of indirect inguinal hernia

  • Bubonocele – Hernia limited to the inguinal canal.
  • Funicular – Hernia stops just above the testis.
  • Complete/scrotal – Hernia reaches bottom of scrotum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male comes to the casualty with symptoms of diminished breathing, bradycardia, hypotension, and pin-point pupil. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Opioid intoxication is the most probable diagnosis in the above given clinical scenario. Opioids include morphine, heroin, codeine, etc.

Opioid Overdose Symptoms:

  • Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils(miosis)
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Shallow breathing
  • Hypothermia

Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS):

  • Mydriasis
  • Yawning
  • Weakness
  • Insomnia, irritability
  • Tremors, tachycardia
  • Hyperthermia, hypertension
  • Diarrhea
  • Rhinorrhoea
  • Apnoeic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Anxiety
  • Lacrimation
  • Sweating

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presented with acute ST segment elevated anterior myocardial infarction and coronary stenting was performed. At the clinic follow-up, he reported pain over his toes. On examination, coloured skin lesions were observed at both feet (see picture) with tenderness. During follow-up, progressive deterioration in renal functions also developed gradually. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a classical history of atheroembolism also called cholesterol embolism or Blue toe syndrome.

Key points in the history:

  • Patient with ST elevation myocardial infarction presenting with clinical features of limb ischemia (Cyanotic discoloration of the toes with pain and tenderness) following an intraarterial procedure (angioplasty).

Atheroembolism:

  • Atheroembolism is a condition in which multiple small deposits of fibrin, platelets, and cholesterol debris embolize from proximal atherosclerotic lesions or aneurysmal sites.
  • Large protruding aortic atheromas are a source of emboli that may lead to limb ischemia, as well as stroke and renal insufficiency.
  • Atheroembolism may occur after intraarterial procedures like angioplasty (percutaneous coronary intervention).
  • Since atheroemboli to limbs tend to lodge in the small vessels of the muscle and skin and may not occlude the large vessels, distal pulses usually remain palpable.
  • Patients complain of acute pain and tenderness at the site of embolization.
  • Digital vascular occlusion may result in ischemia and the "blue toe" syndrome; digital necrosis and gangrene may develop.
  • Localized areas of tenderness, pallor, and livedo reticularis occur at sites of emboli.
  • Skin or muscle biopsy may demonstrate cholesterol crystals.

questions.text: What is the velocity of X-rays?
questions.solution:
X-ray is an electromagnetic wave. All electromagnetic waves have a constant velocity of 3×108 m/s and no mass. 

The electromagnetic spectrum, from low frequency to high frequency consists of:

Radiowaves < Microwaves < Infrared < Visible light < Ultraviolet < X-rays < Gamma rays

The more the frequency, the more the energy. X-rays are extra-nuclear in origin and gamma rays are intra-nuclear in origin.

questions.text: A pregnant lady presented to the casualty after she was scratched by a street dog  while she was walking on the streets an hour ago.She has only some minor abrasions with no bleeding. What treatment should be offered to her?

choices.text: No treatment as she is pregnant now
Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine
Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccine and Immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
This case is classified under WHO category II since there was no bleeding present at the site of dog-bite and she has to be given Rabies vaccine along with local wound cleaning. 

Since Rabies is a lethal disease, there is no contraindication for post-exposure prophylaxis following high risk exposures, even in pregnancy,infancy, immunocompromised patients and even in children with AIDS/HIV. 

Note:

Patients taking chloroquine has to be given the vaccine intramuscularly as there is a reduced response to intradermal route. 

For pre-exposure prophylaxis ,previous allergic reaction to any components of the vaccine is a contraindication.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
• The image depicts a fasciotomy of the lower limb.
  • Fasciotomy involves incising the deep muscle fascia and is best carried out via longitudinal incisions of skin, fat and fascia.
  • The muscle will be seen bulging out through the fasciotomy opening.
  • The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia.
  • This give access to the two posterior compartments and to the peroneal and anterior compartments of the leg.

questions.text: While performing a subtotal thyroidectomy, accidental ligation of which artery can potentially lead to hypoparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Truncal ligation of the inferior thyroid artery can potentially result in hypoparathyroidism. Both superior and inferior parathyroid glands receive their blood from the inferior thyroid artery which arises from the subclavian arteries.Hence during thyroidectomy, only capsular branches closer to the thyroid gland should be ligated.

The inferior parathyroid glands may have a variable blood supply, from either the ascending branch of the inferior thyroid arteries or the thyroid ima artery.

questions.text: Which of the following case scenarios depict a mode of transmission that carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV?

choices.text: A 23-year-old drug addict sharing syringes during intravenous drug abuse
A 15-year-old thalassemic adolescent undergoing blood transfusion
A 30-year-old man engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners
A 27-year-old nurse accidentally injuring herself while drawing blood

questions.solution:
Blood transfusion carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV.

Salient features of transmission of HIV:

  • The highest risk of acquiring HIV from an infected source is via blood transfusion > needle sharing during drug abuse > receptive anal intercourse > needle-stick injury > vaginal & oral sexual intercourse.
  • The most common mode of transmission worldwide is sexual transmission (heterosexual in India) > mother to child > least common modes are blood transfusion & needle-stick injury.
  • Male to female transmission > female to male transmission.
  • Viral load is highest in blood > semen > vaginal fluid > breastmilk & saliva and minimal to absent in tears, sweat & urine.

questions.text: The fasting blood glucose levels of a hypothetical population form two overlapping distributions, one of the people with diabetes(B), and another one of the people without diabetes(A) resembling those in the figure shown below. A test was done with the cutoff for diagnosing diabetes as 120mg/ dl, what does the area D represent?

choices.text: Diabetics correctly classified as the same
Non diabetics correctly  classified as the same
Non diabetics  incorrectly classified as diabetics
Diabetics  incorrectly classified as non diabetics

questions.solution:
Area D represents the false positives (Non-diabetics incorrectly classified as diabetics)

Area C represents the False Negatives (Diabetics incorrectly classified as non-diabetics)

Area B represents the True positives (Diabetics correctly classified as the same) and the false negatives 

Area A represents the  True negatives (Non-diabetics correctly classified as the same) and the false positives 

Note :

From the above distribution curves, it is apparent that the choice of the cutoff point will determine the sensitivity and the specificity of the test.

For example, reducing the cutoff to a lower value will increase the sensitivity, but the specificity will be low and the number of false-positive results would be unacceptably high. Similarly, by plotting on a distribution curve think of what would happen if the cutoff point is increased.

A test can only be 100% specific and 100% sensitive if there is no overlap between the curves, this kind of situation doesn't commonly occur and when it does, the disease may be so obvious that no diagnostic testing is required. Hence it is often best to use a combination of tests to diagnose a disease. A highly sensitive (usually relatively cheap) followed by a more specific test.

questions.text: A 10-day-old male infant presented with poor feeding, multiple cyanotic episodes, and recurrent generalized convulsions. A peculiar maple syrup odour was present in urine. What is the deficient enzyme in this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) which is due to deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH).

Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain amino acids. Their decarboxylation is accomplished by BCKDH using thiamine (vitamin B1) pyrophosphate as a coenzyme.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man, who is a heavy smoker for the past 30 years presents to the clinic with painless hematuria for the past 2 months. After the initial investigations, the doctor suspects bladder cancer. Which of the tumor markers is likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nuclear matrix protein 22 (NMP 22) is elevated in patients with bladder cancer. NMP-22 cutoff levels for bladder cancer detection is >10 units/mL.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the device given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Multiload Cu250, which is one of the copper-containing IUCDs. Formation of the cervical mucus plug is not the mechanism of action. However, progesterone-containing IUCDs can alter the cervical mucus along with the local effects.

The various mechanisms of action of a copper-containing IUCD are:

  • Preventing sperm motility and viability within the uterine cavity by causing a localized inflammatory response.
  • Provokes uterine contractility through prostaglandin release and increases the tubal peristalsis. The egg moves more rapidly into uterine cavity before the development of chorionic villi and thus is unable to implant.
  • Leucocytes infiltrate the endometrium and engulf the fertilized egg.
  • Enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue interfere with the implantation of the fertilized ovum

Some IUCDs like CuT-380A are effective for up to 10 years. Copper IUDs are helpful for emergency contraception if placed within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

Contraindications for use of copper T include

  • Wilson disease 
  • Sensitivity to copper 
  • Pregnancy or suspected pregnancy 
  • Acute pelvic inflammatory disease or STI at the time of insertion
  • A congenital uterine abnormality that distorts the shape of the uterine cavity making insertion difficult
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Confirmed or suspicion of uterine or cervical malignancy/neoplasia 
Abnormal uterine bleeding of unknown origin
 
Other options:
Option A: Impair sperm motility - Copper ions released from the device create a toxic environment for sperm, reducing their motility and viability.
Option B: Increase the motility of tubes - The IUD can increase uterine contractility, which may affect overall reproductive tract motility.
Option C: Enzymatic changes to prevent implantation - Copper ions alter the endometrial environment, potentially interfering with implantation.

questions.text: Riya was found to have a height of more than 95 percentile for her age and an arm-span to height ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, and long slender fingers. An image of her hands showing two characteristic signs is provided below. What other complications can be expected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Marfan's syndrome. Subluxation of the lens is a known complication. 

Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist.

Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist

Features of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S)

  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Myopia due to upward dislocation of the lens (bilateral ectopic lentis)
  • Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity
  • Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved)
  • Flat feet
  • Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax)
  • Nearsightedness
  • Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apnea
