questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done and shown below. The neonate is taken up for surgery and an apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is seen. Which type of ileal atresia has this feature?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of type 3 ileal atresia.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia whereas abdominal distension is more with ileal atresia. 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction.

  • Jejunal/ileal atresia - Triple bubble appearance
  • Duodenal atresia - Double bubble appearance

A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other bowel anomalies. 

In jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is possible. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis. 

Classification of Jejunoileal atresia:

Type

Feature

Type 1

Mucosal web or diaphragm

Type 2

With an atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery

Type 3 a

Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap

Type 3 b

An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap

Type 4

Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was brought to psychiatry OPD. She appeared agitated and claimed that her baby was stolen from the womb by her sister. She was seen talking to herself and has been awake for the past 4 days. Her husband reports that she has been feeling low all the time for 2 weeks. She delivered a healthy female baby 3 weeks back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario the patient is showing features of Postpartum psychosis (depression with psychotic features).

It can often begin within days of the delivery, although the mean time to onset is usually within 2 to 3 weeks of delivery. Characteristically, the patient begins to complain of fatigue, episodes of tearfulness and emotional lability. Later, suspiciousness, confusion, irrational statements, and obsessive concerns about the baby's health and welfare may be present. They eventually develop delusions that involve the idea that the baby is dead or defective. Hallucinations if present may involve voices telling the patient to harm the baby or herself. 

 

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: Serpiginous pattern of skin lesion as shown in the image below is characteristically seen in _____
questions.solution:
Serpiginous/serpent-like skin lesions are seen in Cutaneous Larva Migrans (CLM).

  • CLM is caused by various animal hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense), and the parasite is acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. 
  • The parasitic infection usually begins with an inflamed papule, often located between the toes, where the hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense) larvae enter the skin.
  • Serpentine or linear single-track lines later mark the course of the larvae as they migrate through the epidermis of the trunk and lower extremities. 

  • Cutaneous larva migrans is also known as ground itch or creeping eruption.  Ivermectin is the first line drug for the treatment of cutaneous larva migrans, taken as a single 200 μg/kg oral dose.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency with high-grade fever,  tachypnea, dyspnea, and cough from the last 2 days. His SpO2 was 88%. His chest X-ray findings are shown below. Which of the following is less likely to be considered as a differential?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray finding is suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and tuberculosis is less likely to be a causative disease.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by acute onset, severe dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Etiological factors can be divided into direct and indirect causes of lung injury as follows:

  • Direct lung injury-
    • Pneumonia
    • Aspiration of gastric contents
    • Near drowning
    • Toxic inhalation injury
    • Pulmonary contusion.
    • COVID-19
  • Indirect lung injury-
    • Sepsis
    • Severe trauma like burns, flail chest, head trauma, multiple bone fractures
    • Transfusions
    • Drug overdose
    • Multiple transfusions
    • Pancreatitis
    • Drug overdose.

There are three stages in the development of ARDS:

  1. Exudative phase: Occurs for the first 7 days of the illness. The alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes are injured, with a breach in the tight alveolar barrier. Proinflammatory cytokines like IL-8, IL-1, TNF-α, and LT-B4 lead to the recruitment of neutrophils and the development of a hyaline membrane in the alveoli.
  2. Proliferative phase: Occurs from day 7-21. Recovery from mechanical ventilation is seen in most patients. Some patients may develop pulmonary fibrosis in this stage. Histological recovery is seen in this phase with a shift to lymphocyte predominant infiltrates. Type II pneumocytes proliferate and secrete surfactant with subsequent differentiation to Type I pneumocytes.
  3. Fibrotic phase: Is associated with increased mortality. Extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis are seen.

Chest X-ray features in ARDS:

Chest x-ray features usually develop 12-24 hours after initial lung insult as a result of proteinaceous interstitial edema. Within one week, hyaline membrane occurs due to type 1 pneumocyte damage. There are diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. 

Severity classification of ARDS:

  • Mild: 200 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 300 mmHg
  • Moderate: 100 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 200 mmHg
  • Severe: Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management:

  • Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and high-PEEP.
  • Prone ventilation
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Early neuromuscular blockade

Tuberculosis commonly causes respiratory failure in patients with extensive pulmonary parenchymal involvement, but it is a very rare cause of ARDS.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident (RTA) is put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal commands and both pupils are well reactive. He moves all 4 limbs spontaneously. What is his GCS score
questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient can be documented as Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6, and Pupil-0.

  • Eye-opening to verbal command - 3 
  • In endotracheal intubation, the verbal response cannot be tested. It is documented as NT.
  • Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6
  • Both the pupils are reactive- 0

The total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable (NT).

The GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score:

GCS-P = GCS - PRS

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text:
You notice an obstetrics resident performing the following manoeuvres on a 37-week primigravida. Choose the correctly matched set.
  1. First Leopold
  2. Second Leopold
  3. Third Leopold
  4. Fourth Leopold
questions.solution:
Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's manoeuvres:

  1. Fundal grip (first Leopold):
    • Assesses the uterine fundus.
    • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
    • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. 
    • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

  2. Lateral grip (second Leopold): 
    • Assesses the fetal orientation.
    • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
    • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
    • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
    • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
    • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

  3. Pawlik's grip / 1st pelvic grip (third Leopold):
    • Assesses the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis.
    • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
    • If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.

  4. Deep pelvic grip / 2nd pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):
    • Assesses the engagement, attitude of the fetal head and determine the degree of descent.
    • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
    • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.
    • If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by the neck may be differentiated readily from the head.
    • It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

questions.text: As a participant in the Indian Academy of Paediatrics quiz, you are asked to mark the type of inheritance in MELAS.  The pedigree chart shown in the image below is provided to explain which family members may be affected (coloured in red). Which of the following will you choose?
questions.solution:
The type of inheritance in MELAS is mitochondrial, which manifests as mitochondrial myopathy, encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes.

Mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperms contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.
  • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.
  • 80% of mitochondrial DNA codes for mitochondrial RNA, and therefore most mitochondrial DNA mutations lead to functional problems, which may be manifested as muscle disorders.

The following pedigree shows the mitochondrial inheritance pattern-

questions.text: In which of the following disease conditions is “Row of tombstones” appearance characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
The Row of Tombstone appearance is classically described in the histopathology of a fresh blister of Pemphigus Vulgaris or Drug-induced pemphigus.

  • Suprabasal splitting of the epidermis leads to blister formation, with the basal layer still remaining adherent to the basement membrane, and gives the resemblance to the row of the tombstone.

Image: Suprabasal acantholysis in pemphigus showing the characteristic "row of tombstone" appearance (H and E, ×100)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was prepared for emergency surgery and an endotracheal tube was inserted. Following intubation, end-tidal carbon dioxide was detected. But, his oxygen saturation dropped to 60% and there were no breath sounds audible over the left hemithorax. This is mostly because of _______.
questions.solution:
Detection of end-tidal CO2 but dropping oxygen saturation with absent breath sounds over the left hemithorax point to endobronchial intubation into the right main bronchus.

Signs of endobronchial intubation:

  • Elevated peak inspiratory pressure (first sign)
  • Asymmetric chest expansion
  • Unilateral breath sounds
  • Drop in oxygen saturation

Capnography and detection of end-tidal CO2 is the surest confirmation for an advanced airway placement, but it does not differentiate endotracheal from endobronchial intubation.

questions.text: An infant presented with yellow discolouration of the skin, poor feeding, and seizures. Investigations revealed total bilirubin- 40 mg/dL and unconjugated bilirubin- 32 mg/dL. Phenobarbitone was administered while blood was being arranged for an exchange transfusion. However, there was no improvement. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with poor feeding and seizures is indicative of kernicterus. This accompanied with unconjugated hyperbilrubinemia is highly suggestive of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1.

No improvement in bilirubin levels following the administration of phenobarbital further supports the diagnosis. 

Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace enzyme activity and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. 

Kernicterus occurs because the unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and hence crosses the blood-brain barrier. 

Phenobarbital is an enzyme inducer. Its administration can be used to differentiate between type 1 and type 2 Crigler-Najjar.

  • Enzyme induction by phenobarbital leads to improved conjugation of bilirubin leading to a reduction in total bilirubin level in type 2 Crigler-Najjar syndrome.
  • No improvement is seen in type 1 as the enzyme activity is absent and therefore cannot be induced.

Inherited unconjugated hyperbilirubinemias (Autosomal Recessive) include:

 

Crigler-Najjar type  I

Crigler-Najjar type II

 Gilbert Syndrome
UDP-GT Activity  Absent Markedly reduced Reduced
Serum bilirubin 20 - 45 mg/dl <20 mg/dl Generally <3 mg/dl
Pheno-barbital effect on serum bilirubin No effect Reduction Reduction
Outcome Kernicterus Usually benign, kernicterus is rare  Benign
Prevalence Rare  Rare  Common

Note: Rotor syndrome causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text:
The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
  1. Glasgow coma scale
  2. Respiratory Rate
  3. Pulse Rate
  4. Systolic BP
  5. Mechanism of Injury
questions.solution:
The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient.

Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

The score range is 0–12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury. 

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 3 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoma cervix is undergoing the treatment modality in the image given below. Which of the following elements is most commonly used in this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows brachytherapy being used to treat carcinoma cervix. Cesium is the most common radioactive agent used for the same.

In the majority of these treatments, radiation applicators are placed within a cavity of the body such as the bronchus (airway) in the lung, esophagus, vagina, cervix of the uterus.

The primary advantage of internal radiation is the ability to deliver a higher radiation dose while the normal tissues receive less radiation since the radiation sources are placed within the tumor. Both Iridium and cesium have been used as radioactive sources to give internal radiation.

questions.text: Scabies in neonates differs from that of adults in that it affects _____
questions.solution:
• Scabies in neonates differs from that of adults in that it affects face, scalp palm, and soles.
  • However, in adults, it involves area of the finger webs, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, back, buttocks, and external genitals.

questions.text: At what point do you begin plotting on a partogram when the first contractions occur?
questions.solution:
In a partograph, labor is graphed and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.

A partograph was designed by WHO for use in developing countries. Partograph is similar for nulliparas and multiparas.

Active phase starts at 3cm cervical dilatation and progress should be no slower than 1cm/hour.

A 4 hour wait is recommended before intervention when the active phase is slow.

In the modified partograph, there is no plotting of the latent phase. The partograph is plotted once active labor begins.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask is
questions.solution:
The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

A conventional oxygen mask is a simple face mask that is used routinely in hospitals. It covers the nose and mouth of the patient. There are 2 exhalation ports through which the patient exhales carbon dioxide. This mask is held in place with elastic around the back of the head and a metal piece that fits over the nose. It provides 40% to 60% of O2 concentration and delivers O2 at the rate of 6 to 10 L/min.

Conventional oxygen therapy includes all the devices that are used in routine practices. It includes nasal prongs, low-flow nasal cannula, or masks. It is the main supportive treatment administered to patients after planned extubation. 

Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min)  Approximate FiO2
Nasal cannula  1-6  0.24-0.44 
Simple face mask  6-10 0.40-0.60
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15 0.90-1.00 
Venturi mask  2-15  0.24-0.60

Oxygen delivery devices can be broadly divided into low flow oxygen devices (eg: nasal cannula, simple face mask, non-rebreathing mask) and high flow oxygen devices (eg: venturi mask).

Important note- If the question is about the maximum flow rate with the conventional oxygen mask, it would be 10L/ min. Whereas if the question is asking about the maximum oxygen flow rate with conventional oxygen therapy, then it would include all the conventionally used devices. Therefore, the answer would be 15L/min.

The below image shows a nasal cannula, which delivers oxygen at 1-6 L/min.

The below image shows a non-rebreathing mask that provides an oxygen flow rate of up to 10-15 L/min.

The below image shows a venturi mask, which delivers oxygen at 2-15 L/min.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
A thirsty child signifies some dehydration, not severe dehydration. 

Clinical features of severe dehydration in a child include:

  • Drowsy, lethargic or unconscious
  • Drinks poorly or not able to drink
  • Sunken eyes and absent tears
  • Sunken fontanelle
  • Deep breathing
  • Skin pinch goes back very slowly (recoil in >2 seconds)
  • Tachycardia, with bradycardia in most severe cases
  • Weak, thready, or impalpable pulse
  • Prolonged capillary refill
  • Cold, mottled, and cyanotic extremities
  • Minimal urine output 

 

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

questions.text: Which of the following blood components does not carry the risk of transmitting cytomegalovirus infection?
questions.solution:
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is an acellular component and generally does not transmit viral infections.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infects >50% of the general population and is transmitted by infected passenger WBCs in transfused PRBCs or platelet components. Cellular components that are leukocyte-reduced have a decreased risk of transmitting CMV.

Infectious complications of blood transfusion include: 

  • Viral infections: Hepatitis C virus, hepatitis B virus, HIV, cytomegalovirus
  • Bacterial contamination: sudden and fulminant onset of fever, chills, septic shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
    • Platelet concentrates stored at room temperature: gram-positive and coagulase-negative staphylococci
    • PRBCs: Gram-negative bacteria like Yersinia, Pseudomonas, Serratia, Acinetobacter, and Escherichia species
  • Parasites: Malaria, Babesiosis, Chaga's disease
  • Others: Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD)

Related Pearl: Blood components

Component Volume     (1 unit) Content Clinical response, increase in  Storage temperature Shelf-life
Whole blood 450 ml RBCs, platelets, plasma Hb and plasma volume    
Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) 300-350 ml RBCs

Hb by 1 g/dl

Hematocrit by 3%

1° to 6°C

ACD/CPD-21 days, CPD-A-35 days, additive-42 days
Random donor platelets (RDP) 50-70 ml Platelets platelet count by 5000-10,000/µL 20 to 24°C 5 days
Single donor apheretic platelets (SDP*) 200-400 ml Platelets platelet count by 30,000/µL
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) 200-250 ml Coagulation factors, protein C, protein S, anti thrombin coagulation factors by 2% -18 to -30°C 1 year
Cryoprecipitate 10-15 ml fibrinogen, factor VIII, VWF 80 IU Factor VIII -30 °C 1 years

 

*SDP is obtained by collecting multiple units of platelets from a single donor using apheretic technology. 

1 SDP = 6 RDP

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows ventricular tachycardia.

The features in the above ECG suggesting the diagnosis are as follows:

  • Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows)
  • Absence of the P waves
  • Rate >100/min- in the given ECG, it is ~180 beats/min (1500/no. of small boxes between two R waves)

Ventricular fibrillation would have no discreet QRS complexes. The given ECG shows ventricular fibrillation:

questions.text: A man accidentally took a bath with overheated water. A few hours later, he developed the given lesion on his shoulders and chest. Following spontaneous rupture 3 days later, the base of the lesion was erythematous and blanches on touch. What is the time taken by these wounds to heal?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of second-degree superficial burns. They usually heal with minimal scarring in 10–14 days unless they become infected.

Second-degree burns are divided into two types: 

  • Superficial Dermal burns are erythematous and painful, blanch to touch, and often blister. They heal in 10–14 days.
  • Deep dermal burns involve the reticular dermis, appear more pale with erythmatous regions, do not blanch to touch, but remain painful to pinprick. They heal in 4–8 weeks.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree superficial (partial-thickness) Second-degree deep (partial-thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: A 9-day-old infant has elevated TSH level and low T4 level on newborn screening. If this condition is left untreated, which of the following is the infant likely to demonstrate in the first few weeks of life?
questions.solution:
Elevated TSH levels and low T4 levels in a 9-day-old infant are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism, and prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia is an early sign. It is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation.

Congenital hypothyroidism is associated with hypotonia, lethargy, sluggishness, and constipation.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Wilson's disease?

choices.text: AP1S1 gene is essential for normal functioning
Siblings of affected children have 1 in 4 risk of the disease

questions.solution:
Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:

  • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
  • Helps excrete free copper in bile.

Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues. It is an autosomal recessive condition. So, siblings of affected children have a 1 in 4 chance.

Intracellular trafficking of ATP7B (Wilson's disease) and ATP7A (Menke's disease) genes are regulated by an adaptor protein encoded by the AP1S1 gene. Mutations in this gene result in a syndrome with features of both Wilson's and Menke's diseases. It is called MEDNIK syndrome:

  • Mental retardation
  • Enteropathy
  • Deafness
  • Neuropathy
  • Ichthyosis
  • Keratodermia.

questions.text: A 55 year old female complains of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts ballooning of disc spaces leading to biconcave shape of vertebral body known as ‘Cod fish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T score less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

  • Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse
  • Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like pelvis
  • Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)
  • Loss of trabeculae in proximal femur area.

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?
  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Of the given list/combination of instruments 1, 2, 4, 6 are commonly used in the cesarean section. 

Cesarean section:

It is an operative procedure in which the fetuses are delivered through an incision on the abdominal and uterine walls. This would include only those fetuses that are delivered after the end of the 28th week at the same time exclude delivery through an abdominal incision where the fetus might be lying free in the abdominal cavity, either following uterine rupture or in secondary abdominal pregnancy. 

The given image summarizes the various instruments used in the lower segment cesarean section.

 

Bard-Parker blade (scalpel with blade) has a handle with a notch to fit the blade. It is usually held by pencil grip. Commonly for abdominal incisions, we use blade no: 22. Other uses include incision of skin and sub-cutaneous tissues, cutting the clamped pedicles, and performing sharp dissections. 

The given image shows various Bard-Parker blades.

 

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor. 

 

Alli's forceps: It is identified by the distal blades and a tip that has teeth that do not oppose each other. There is also a lock in the proximal part. 

Uses:

  • To catch hold of the margins and angles of the uterine flaps in LSCS after the delivery of the baby in settings where the Green-Armytage hemostatic clamp is not available.
  • To catch hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • To hold the apex of the episiotomy wound during the repair.
  • To catch hold of the margins of the peritoneum, rectus sheath, vaginal mucosa during the repair.
  • To catch hold of the torn ends of the sphincter ani externus prior to suture in the repair of complete perineal tear.

The given image shows Alli's forceps.

 

Green armytage forceps have a broad tip as shown in the image and hence are used to compress a wide area. It is used as a hemostat in caesarian sections. In LSCS (Lower segment Caesarean section), the cut uterine edges can bleed and Green Armytage forceps are applied to the edge of the incision for hemostasis.

 

Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualization of the cervix, vaginal fornices, and for performing pap smears.

The instrument shown in the image is Cusco’s speculum.

 

Shirodkar's uterine holding clamp has blades with curved transverse bars with gaps between them when it is locked. This gap makes it atraumatic and is used to lift, hold and steady the uterus during sling surgeries and tubal procedures. 

The image below shows Shirodkar's uterine clamp.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: In your internal medicine ward rounds,  you are reviewing a case of bilateral renal artery stenosis. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS).

In renal artery stenosis, blood flow to the kidney is reduced, thereby reducing blood flow to the afferent arterioles. Hence, constriction of efferent arterioles is needed to maintain hydrostatic pressure within the glomerulus in order to maintain GFR.

ACEIs and ARBs inhibit efferent renal arteriolar vasoconstriction. In bilateral RAS, this causes a decline in the GFR within a few days of starting the drug.

Note: Bilateral renal artery stenosis has been classically considered as an absolute contraindication to the use of ACE inhibitors. However, new studies show that they may be used in some cases with careful monitoring.

questions.text: While examining the oral cavity of a patient with lichen planus. you notice the following lesion. Which of the following describes the lesion best?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Wickham striae, which are whitish lines visible in the papules of oral lichen planus a condition reclassified as pre-malignant in the WHO digital manual for the early diagnosis of oral neoplasia.

Clinically, oral lichen planus can present as Wickham striae, white papules, white plaque, erythema, erosion, or blisters. They may be symmetrical and bilateral. Buccal mucosa, dorsum of the tongue, and gingivae are commonly affected. Early diagnosis and management play an important role in the prevention of progression to malignancy. The management involves:

  • Maintenance of good oral hygiene
  • Elimination of precipitating factors
  • Topical steroids
  • Topical isotretinoin gel & tretinoin ointment

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

Various factors can precipitate the disease like:

  • Viruses like: Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpes viruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), Varicella zoster
  • HLA-A3, HLA-5 association
  • Environmental factors like:
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 P"s of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

Complications of lichen planus includes:

  • Hair: Patches of cicatricial scarring alopecia
  • Nails: Various nail changes are seen associated with lichen planus. 
    • Dorsal Nail Pterygium: Most specific nail change in lichen planus where the fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium formation.
    • Thinning of the nail plate: Most common nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions.
    • Pup-tent sign: Elevation of nail in the shape of a tent
    • Trachonychia: All 20 nails of hands and feet undergo dystrophy
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
    • Longitudinal melanonychia in lichen planus of the nail bed
    • Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)
  • Mucous membranes: Squamous cell carcinoma may occur on the lip, buccal mucosa or gum margin
 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image : Trachonychia

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator of iron depletion in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Serum Ferritin is the most sensitive indicator of Iron deficiency Anemia in pregnant women as its concentrations are not affected with recent intake of iron rich foods.

Confirmation of Iron deficiency Anemia:

  • Serum ferritin concentration <15 μg/L indicates Iron deficiency anemia.
  • However, treatment needs to be initiated when the concentration falls below 30 μg/L, as this indicates early iron depletion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent late-trimester abortions is in preterm labor, presumed to be due to chorioamnionitis. She has received one dose of betamethasone injection. This is a precious pregnancy and the relatives are concerned about prematurity-related complications in the baby. Which of the following is useful for assessing lung maturity in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio (L/S ratio) is an amniotic fluid test used to assess fetal lung maturity. L/S ratio of < 2 in amniotic fluid indicates lung immaturity. 

Surfactant starts appearing in the fetal lung by 20 weeks of gestation. Levels indicating lung maturity are detected after 35 weeks.

Surfactant is a complex mixture of lipids, proteins, and carbohydrates produced by type II pneumocytes in the lung epithelium. The absence of surfactant in the liquid film lining the alveoli causes an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse. If not treated, such atelectasis leads to increased work of breathing, intrapulmonary shunting, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, hypoxia, and eventually respiratory failure. 

The relative concentration of the phospholipids lecithin (L) and sphingomyelin (S) is an indicator of lung maturity. The outward flow of pulmonary secretions from the fetal lungs into the amniotic fluid maintains the level of lecithin and sphingomyelin equally until 32–33 weeks gestation when the lecithin concentration begins to increase significantly while sphingomyelin remains nearly the same. An L–S ratio of 2.5 or more indicates fetal lung maturity while an L/S ratio of less than 1.5 is associated with a high risk of infant respiratory distress syndrome.

Other tests done to assess fetal lung maturity are:

  • Shake test/bubble test
  • Phosphatidyl glycerol measurement
  • Surfactant:albumin ratio
  • Lamellar body counts

questions.text: Patients with the following condition(s) should be considered for bilateral adrenalectomy:

choices.text: Unlocalised primary tumour of the adrenals

questions.solution:
Indications of bilateral adrenalectomy: 

  • Bilateral ACTH-independent disease
  • Ectopic ACTH-dependent "Cushing’s Syndrome"
  • Irresectable or unlocalised primary tumour

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of swelling behind the knee for the last 3 years. On evaluation, he is diagnosed to have a popliteal artery aneurysm. Beyond what diameter is repair indicated?
questions.solution:
Popliteal artery aneurysm repair is indicated when the diameter exceeds 2–3 cm, owing to the risk of thrombosis, embolism, or rupture and when they are symptomatic.

Related Pearl: Indication for operative repair of aneurysm

Condition Criteria for surgical repair
Symptomatic aneurysm  Any size
Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >5.5 cm
Descending thoracic aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >6 cm
Abdominal aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >5.5 cm
Popliteal artery aneurysm - asymptomatic >2-3 cm
Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm in Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve >4-5 cm

Rapidly growing aneurysms 

>0.5 cm/year for ascending aortic aneurysms

> 1cm/year for descending aortic aneurysms

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency room following a motorcycle collision. On examination, the patient is drowsy and has decreased blood pressure due to bleeding from multiple injuries. 1 unit of packed RBCs has been obtained from the blood bank. What is the correct procedure for blood transfusion?

choices.text: The blood should be brought to room temperature before the transfusion
Transfusion should be started within one hour of removal from the refrigerator
Transfusion of PRBC should be completed within 4 hours
The rate of transfusion of PRBC is 50mL per hour

questions.solution:
The transfusion of packed RBCs (PRBC) should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours after the removal from the blood fridge. 

There is an increased risk of bacterial proliferation and loss of the function of blood components after they are removed from the storage temperatures. Hence, the transfusion should be started within 30 minutes of receiving the components from the blood bank. The packed RBCs should be infused at a rate of 100-150mL/hour. Warming of blood is not needed when the transfusion is at normal rates. The transfusion should be completed within a maximum period of 4 hours.

Duration times for transfusion
Blood products  Start transfusion  Complete transfusion
Whole blood / PRBC Within 30 minutes of removing from refrigerator

≤ 4 hours 

Discard unit if this period is exceeded
Platelet concentrate  Immediately Within 30 minutes
Fresh frozen plasma As soon as possible Within 30 minutes
Cryoprecipitate As soon as possible Within 30 minutes

questions.text: A study was conducted on a group of 500 patients having carcinoma lung and another group of 300 was chosen from the general population. Both these groups were questioned on their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution: This is a case–control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people constitute the controls, and the study is done from effect to cause as the disease has already occurred.

questions.text: A patient presents with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral hemiplegia is seen in Weber’s syndrome.

Weber’s syndrome occurs due to infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of the PCA. It affects the cerebral peduncle, especially medially, and damages III cranial nerve and the pyramidal fibers. It results in contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy.

Claude's syndrome is a distinctive brainstem syndrome characterized by ipsilateral third cranial nerve palsy with contralateral hemiataxia. This is due to an intrinsic or extrinsic lesion in the midbrain.

Related Pearl: Stroke syndromes with visual symptoms

Disease

Site of lesion

Clinical features

Anton’s syndrome

B/L infarction in the distal PCAs

Cortical blindness, with denial or unawareness of blindness

Balint’s syndrome

Low flow in the “watershed region” between distal PCA and MCA territories

Palinopsia

Asimultanagnosia

Optic ataxia

Ocular apraxia

 

Weber’s syndrome

Midbrain

I/L CN III palsy

C/L hemiplegia

Dorsal midbrain

Tetrad of symptoms:

Loss of upgaze

Light-near dissociation

Convergence – retraction nystagmus

Lid retraction

Benedikt syndrome

Midbrain

Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy

Contralateral hemiparesis

Contralateral cerebellar ataxia

Holmes tremor

Choreoathetosis

questions.text: A newborn was born to a 19-year-old female patient with the following defect. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The above image shows, gastroschisis which represents a congenital anomaly characterized by a defect in the anterior abdominal wall. The abdominal contents protrude through this defect. It is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age.

Unlike omphalocele, there is no overlying sac and the size of the defect is usually <4 cm.

Other conditions:

Omphalocele:

Umbilical Hernia:

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: Which of the following is the best vein for total parenteral nutrition?
questions.solution:
The subclavian vein is considered the most suitable vein for total parenteral nutrition, as the catheter lies flat on the chest wall, which optimizes nursing care. Moreover, the rate of infection with subclavian venous access is lowest when compared to jugular access and femoral access.

Disadvantages of subclavian vein central venous access:

  • Subclavian vein stenosis
  • Pneumothorax

questions.text: A G2P1 woman presents to the casualty at 30 weeks with a history of self-limiting painless bleeding PV 3 hours ago. On examination, BP - 110/70 mmHg and PR - 80 bpm. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Transvaginal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis
Start injection corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of antepartum haemorrhage (APH) due to placenta previa (painless bleeding PV). The next step in the management is to confirm the diagnosis with transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) as the patient is stable.

Transabdominal ultrasound (TAS) is used to detect the cause of APH.

If the placenta is in the lower uterine segment on TAS, confirmation of placenta previa is done by TVS. TVS provides a clearer image of the relationship between the edge of the placenta and the internal cervical os than TAS.

Approach to placenta previa after confirmation with TVS:

  • Minor placenta previa - repeat USG at 36 weeks
  • Major placenta previa or accreta - USG at 32 weeks followed by elective caesarean delivery
  • Bleeding present - individual management

On TAS, if the placenta is in the upper uterine segment with evidence of retroplacental blood clot, abruptio placenta is suspected. 

Per vaginal examination in placenta previa must not be done as it may further separate the placenta and cause excessive bleeding. However, transvaginal ultrasound is safe as long as the probe is 2-3 cm away from the cervix.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in patients with a platelet disorder?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis is highly suggestive of a coagulation disorder, not a platelet disorder.

Bleeding diathesis can occur due to:

  • Platelet disorders - mucocutaneous bleeding like petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, epistaxis, menorrhagia, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeds
  • Coagulation disorders - hemarthrosis, muscle hematomas, and bleeding into soft tissues
  • Disorders of the vessel wall (Henoch-Schönlein purpura, scurvy) - purpura and ecchymosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was admitted following a crush injury to his left leg. Two days later, his urine/plasma creatinine levels are < 20. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and urine/ plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is suggestive of renal AKI due to rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis.

Rhabdomyolysis is a serious complication of crush injuries. It leads to muscle breakdown, releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney injury by the following mechanisms:

  • Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT
  • Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts
  • Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI)
Indices Prerenal Renal
Spot urine sodium (mEq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) <1% >2%
Fractional excretion of urea (FEUrea) <35% >35%
Urine osmolality (mOsm/kg) >500 <350
BUN to serum creatinine ratio >20:1 <10:1
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1
Urinary sediment Nil or hyaline casts only Renal tubular epithelial casts, muddy brown granular casts

questions.text: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus.

Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG.

The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with a fever for the past 5 days. On examination, tender lesions were found on his extremities as marked below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is infective endocarditis.

Tender violaceous subcutaneous nodules in the fingers shown in the image are Osler nodes. They usually occur in the pads of fingers and toes but can also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis include:

  • Roth spots: These are are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centres.
  • Janeway lesions: They are nontender, slightly raised haemorrhages on the palms and soles. The image is shown below.

questions.text: In a suspected case of irritable bowel syndrome, which of the following investigations is not recommended?

choices.text: Stool examination for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
A stool fat test is not recommended in a suspected case of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

  • Complete blood count
  • Sigmoidoscopic examination
  • Stool examination for ova and parasites
  • 3-week lactose-free diet

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the clinic because she is feeling excessively tired these days. She is unable to carry out her day-to-day household works. She says that for the past few months she is having excessive and very frequent menstrual bleeding. On examination, she appears pale, with a smooth tongue. Peripheral smear shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body?
questions.solution:
The patient has features of iron deficiency anemia due to excessive menstrual bleeding. Serum ferritin is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body.

The majority of the patients with iron deficiency anemia present with easy fatigability, tachycardia, palpitations, and dyspnea on exertion. Severe deficiency causes skin and mucosal changes like

  • smooth tongue
  • brittle nails
  • koilonychia- spooning of nails
  • cheilosis- fissures at the corner of the mouth
  • pica- craving for specific foods that are not rich in iron.

Laboratory investigation of iron deficiency anemia

The peripheral smear will show small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) cells with an increased area of central pallor. Pencil-shaped cells can be seen which is called poikilocytosis.

Serum iron levels- It represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. The normal range for the serum iron is 50–150 μg/dL. It is decreased in iron deficiency anemia.

Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)- It is an indirect measure of the circulating transferrin. The normal levels are 300–360 μg/dL. The levels are increased in IDA.

Transferrin saturation- The normal levels are 25–50%. The levels are decreased in IDA.

Serum ferritin- Free iron is toxic to the body. Therefore it is bound to a protein called apoferritin to form ferritin. Adult males have serum ferritin values averaging 100 μg/L, while adult females have levels averaging 30 μg/L. The serum ferritin level is the most convenient laboratory test to estimate iron stores. It is decreased in IDA.

Evaluation of bone marrow iron stores- can be done by performing bone marrow biopsy and using the Prussian stain to stain the iron stores. It is rarely done these days due to the availability of the serum ferritin estimation tests.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

Basic life support involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat.

Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

Other options: 

Option B: Jaw thrust- Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

 

Option D: Manual inline stabilization is a maneuver that limits external head and neck movement in patients with cervical spine injuries. Fingers and palms of both hands are used to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to ensure successful airway intervention.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

The rash visualized in the image is a malar rash. It is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Cutaneous manifestations seen in SLE are:

  • Acute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (malar rash)
  • Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus
  • Discoid lupus erythematosus- DLE (discoid rash)
  • Ulcerations in the oral mucosa
  • Alopecia- it is a non-scarring alopecia in the majority of the cases. However, patients with DLE will have scarring alopecia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old​ female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is carcinoma esophagus. Barium study in Carcinoma of the esophagus will show irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins

Option C- Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. In a barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophageal wall. The image depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

Option D- Esophageal web

questions.text: Given below instrument is used:
questions.solution:
Image shows kehr’s T tube with vertical and horizontal limb.
It is used after exploration of CBD i.e. horizontal limb is placed in CBD and vertical limb is brought out as drain.

It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.
Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimise the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal.
However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones, some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 female patient was admitted to the labor room in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the fetus was found to be in occipitoposterior position. The most appropriate management would be?

choices.text: Wait and watch for progress of labour

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for pregnant women in labour whose fetus is in occipitoposterior position is to wait and watch for progress of labour. 

  • In majority of the cases, occiput rotates through 3/8th of circle and baby is born as occipitoanterior.
  • Hence when diagnosis of occipitoposterior is made, labour is allowed to proceed in a similar manner to normal labour when there are good uterine contractions and favourable pelvis.

Indications of caesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labour
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstertical indications.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features can be seen in a patient presenting with accidental haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Abruptio placenta is also known as accidental haemorrhage or premature separation of placenta. Tender uterus is seen in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is defined as premature separation of a normally situated placenta. It is of the following types:

  • Concealed
  • Revealed
  • Mixed

Clinical features of abruptio placenta:

 Features

Revealed

Concealed

General condition

Proportionate to visible blood loss

Shock may be pronounced which may be out of proportion to visible bleeding.

Symptoms

Abdominal discomfort or pain followed by bleeding

Abdominal acute intense pain

No or minimal bleeding

Uterine height

Proportionate to the period of gestation

Maybe disproportionately enlarged

FHS

Usually present

Usually absent

 In mixed type, features of concealed variety will be predominant.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding adenomyosis?
questions.solution:
Patients with adenomyosis commonly present with symptoms of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.

Adenomyosis (endometriosis interna) is the ingrowth of stromal and glandular components of the endometrium directly into the myometrium. It usually occurs following vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or in conditions with an excess of estrogen. Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. They commonly present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Other symptoms include pelvic discomfort, backache and dyspareunia.

On per-vaginal examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. This is known as Halban's sign. 

Other options:

Option A: Adenomyosis is more common in multiparous women aged 40 years and above. 

Option B: The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination.

Option D:  A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management because of menorrhagia. Total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localised excision and levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger patients.

The image below is an illustration of adenomyosis.

The image below shows adenomyosis as seen during laparoscopy. The uterus is soft and enlarged; the blue spots represent subserous endometriosis.

questions.text: Which of the following heart diseases is associated with the highest risk of maternal mortality during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Eisenmenger syndrome is the heart disease with the worst prognosis, having a maternal mortality rate of 50%.
  • If antenatal diagnosis of Eisenmenger is made in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised.
  • Most common cause of death in Eisenmenger’s syndrome is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock.
  • Heart diseases and their influence on maternal mortality:
    • Mitral regurgitation: well tolerated
    • Mitral valve prolapse: well tolerated
    • Aortic stenosis: life-threatening with severe stenosis
    • Pulmonary stenosis: well tolerated
    • Eisenmenger syndrome: worst prognosis
  • Eisenmenger syndrome has the highest risk of maternal mortality, whereas the most common cause is mitral stenosis.

questions.text: An elective cesarean section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected contracted pelvis. The abdomen is opened by a modified Pfannenstiel incision and routine steps followed.  The obstetrician made a low transverse uterine incision.  It should be extended by ___

choices.text: Lateral and slightly upward pressure applied with each index finger
Lateral and slightly downward pressure applied with each index finger
Lateral and slightly upward pressure applied with each thumb
Lateral and slightly downward pressure applied with each thumb

questions.solution:
Once the uterus is opened, the incision can be extended by spreading the incision using lateral and slightly upward pressure applied with each index finger.

If the lower uterine segment is thick, then cutting laterally and then slightly upward with bandage scissors will extend the incision.

Note : When scissors are used, the index and midline fingers of the nondominant hand should be insinuated beneath the myometrium and above fetal parts to prevent fetal laceration.

questions.text: All are true regarding confounding factor except ______

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.solution:
A confounding factor is a factor that is associated with both exposure and diseases and is distributed unequally in study and control groups.

For example, if the study is that smoking can lead to oral cancer, then alcoholism can act as a confounding factor as it is individually linked to both smoking and oral cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of painless bleeding during defecation. On examination, a pinkish mass appears at the anal orifice when the patient is asked to strain. It reduces spontaneously when the patient relaxes. What will be the grade of this hemorrhoid?
questions.solution:
Prolapse with spontaneous reduction is suggestive of second-degree hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Grading of hemorrhoids

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

questions.text:
The following are the disease frequencies in a population. Based on the number of cases which of the following is the correct match?

Disease 1: Number of cases last week 42 this week 43
Disease 2: Number of cases last week 2 and present week 42
Disease 3: Number of cases last week 6 and present week 1
questions.solution:
Disease 1- the cases have been almost the same so it has to be endemic.
Disease 2- there is an alarming increase in the number of cases. It has to be an epidemic.
Disease 3- the number of cases has decreased without any explanation so it has to be sporadic.

Epidemic refers to the occurrence of a disease in excess of expected frequency.

A pandemic is an epidemic affecting a large population over a large geographical area crossing international boundaries.

An endemic disease is a regularly occurring disease in a population in expected frequency without any importation from outside.

Sporadic diseases present as scattered cases of infection without relation temporally/spatially.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to the OG clinic with complaints of lower abdominal pain and mild bleeding per vaginum for 2 days at 12 weeks of gestation.  She also complains of excessive vomiting for one week. USG was done and it is given below.  What is the probable diagnosis____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of complete mole.  The USG image shows the characteristic “snowstorm” appearance seen in complete mole.

It is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

Notably, a fetus and amnionic sac are absent. 

Snowstorms in radiology:

  • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
  • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
  • Thyroid pulmonary metastases (chest radiograph)

questions.text: What landmarks would you use before selecting the appropriate size for the device shown?

choices.text: Incisor teeth and tragus of the ear
Corner of mouth and angle of mandible
Tip of nose and angle of mandible
Ala of nose and angle of mandible

questions.solution:
The image shows oropharyngeal airway or Guedel airway of various sizes. The landmarks used for measuring the appropriate size of this device are the corner of the mouth and the angle of the mandible or tragus.



An oropharyngeal airway is an airway adjunct which keeps the tongue from falling back onto the posterior pharynx.

It is essential to choose the correct size since inappropriately sized ones may aggravate airway obstruction. 

These airways should not be used in conscious patients as they may come into contact with the epiglottis and base of tongue. This can cause coughing, retching or laryngospasm if the pharyngeal and laryngeal reflexes are not blunted with local anaesthetic. 

 

Note: Nasopharyngeal airway size is chosen by measuring the distance between the tip of the nose and tragus of the ear. These airways, when well lubricated and inserted with proper technique, can be used in conscious patients to secure an airway.

questions.text: You are a first-year resident. You are asked to prescribe an H.pylori eradication regimen to a patient with peptic ulcer disease. Which of the following drugs will you not include in it?
questions.solution:
Erythromycin is not effective in H pylori eradication.
