questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of obstructive lung disease.

Common pulmonary function tests (PFTs) include

  • Spirometry
  • Measurement of lung volumes
  • Quantitation of diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide(DLCO)

Based on PFTs, lung disorders are broadly classified into:

  1. Obstructive disease
  2. Restrictive disease
  3. Pulmonary vascular disease

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the OPD by parents for a well-baby checkup when you notice the following lesion. They say the lesion has been present since birth and has been decreasing in size. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots.

Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. Therefore, these spots are congenital, and are easily distinguished from the bruises of child abuse. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

They usually fade away during the first year of life, and the parents should be reassured about this.

 Other options:

  • Salmon patch or naevus simplex is small, pink-colored macules that are commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. They are an ill-defined lesion, which develops due to vascular ectasia. (Note: The subungual oil droplets seen in nail psoriasis are also known as salmon patches).
  • Neonatal pustular melanosis is a congenital benign lesion characterized by evanescent superficial pustules, ruptured pustules with fine scales, and hyperpigmented macules. The pustular lesions last for 2-3 days, while the hyperpigmented macules may last for about 3 months.
  • Harlequin color change is a congenital lesion, usually seen in low-birth-weight infants where half of the body in the dependent portion turns red in color, while the other half of the body is pale. This occurs due to an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism. Changing the infant's position causes a reversal of the pattern.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Earliest genetic change in carcinoma pancreas is______.
questions.solution:
• The KRAS2 oncogene is activated in more than 95% of pan­creatic cancers and is thought to be the initiating event in tumori­genesis.
  • Progression of pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia to carcinoma:

questions.text: A probe is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised.  This  procedure is known as?

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.

questions.solution:
Microdochectomy is the surgical removal (excision) of a discharging lactiferous duct. 

A probe or a stiff nylon suture is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision can be made to encompass the entire duct or a periareolar incision is used and the nipple flap dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised.

questions.text: A girl wakes the entire hostel dormitory screaming about a snake in the bathroom. The matron rushes in and sees her pointing at a rope. Which of the following best describes this?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a rope being mistaken for a snake is an illusion. Illusions are perceptions that occur when a sensory stimulus is present but is incorrectly perceived and misinterpreted. 

Delusion Hallucination Illusion
A fixed false belief that is firmly held despite obvious contradictory evidence and that is not consistent with the person's social, educational, and cultural background. Perception in the absence of any external sensory stimulus Incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus.
Eg: A belief that the person is a snake god. Eg: There is nothing in front of you but you can see a snake. Eg: There is a rope in front of you but you see it as a snake.

questions.text: The following anomaly is seen in :
questions.solution:
The above picture depicts Starfish hand and is seen in Achondroplasia.

In these patients, middle finger is shorter than usual resulting in all digits being of equal length (starfish hand). There is separation between middle and ring fingers described as Trident hand.

Other features:

  • Most common form of disproportionate dwarfism.
  • Inheritance is autosomal dominant
  • Usually normal intelligence and sexual development
  • Hands are short and broad
  • Posterior scalloping of vertebrae

questions.text: All of the following are signs of the base of skull fracture except _____.
questions.solution:
Fox sign is bruising seen over the inguinal ligament in acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

Signs of the skull base fracture:

  • Battle sign: Extravasation of blood results in ecchymosis behind the ear at the mastoid process.
  • Racoon eye: Periorbital ecchymoses (black eye)
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea
  • CSF otorrhea
  • Anosmia
  • Cranial nerve palsy: damage to the facial or vestibulocochlear nerve, resulting in vertigo, ipsilateral deafness, or facial paralysis
  • Hemotympanum

Battle sign:

Racoon eyes:

questions.text: The following EEG is that of a 6-year-old girl who is easily distracted in class and exhibits poor scholastic performance. Seizures are precipitated by hyperventilation. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. This is seen in absence seizures.

Absence seizures are characterized by a sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control that lasts only a few seconds. However, there is no post-ictal confusion.

Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and also the seizures.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of antepartum haemorrhage (APH).

Placental abruption or abruptio placenta is the premature separation of a normally situated placenta. The bleeding can be revealed, concealed or mixed type.

Causes of APH:

  • Placental causes:
    • Abruptio placenta (most common)
    • Placenta previa (2nd most common)
    • Circumvallate placenta
    • Circummarginate placenta
  • Fetal causes:
    • Vasa previa
  • Extraplacental causes (local cervicovaginal lesions):
    • Local trauma
    • Varicose veins
    • Cervical polyp
    • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: You would classify a baby as post-term if it is born after ________
questions.solution: Post-term infants are those born after 42 completed weeks of gestation, as calculated from the mother’s last menstrual period, regardless of weight at birth.

questions.text: How many goals does the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) comprise of?
questions.solution:
The Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) are comprised of 17 goals.

These were set as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030.  These goals consist of a total of 169 targets. SDGs replaced the Millennium Development Goals on 1st January 2016. 

The 2030 agenda consists of five P's: 

  • People
  • Planet
  • Prosperity
  • Peace
  • Partnership

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presented with persistent upper abdominal pain and weight loss. Ultrasound revealed a lesion in the right lobe of the liver and contrast-enhanced CT was suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following tumor markers can be elevated in this patient?
  1. Alpha fetoprotein 
  2. PIVKA-2
  3. Alpha-2-macroglobulin
  4. Glypican 
  5. Neurotensin
questions.solution:
Alpha-2-macroglobulin and neurotensin are not tumor markers of HCC. 

Tumor markers of HCC are:

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
    • Normal (<20 ng/mL),
    • Elevated (21–400 ng/mL), and
    • Diagnostic for HCC (>400 ng/mL). 
  • Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonist - II (PIVKA-II) also called des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP)
  • Glypican 3.

questions.text: The ultrasonogram shows the diameter of the fetal head which is taken as a reference for engagement. Which diameter does this refer to?
questions.solution:
The fetal head is said to be engaged when the biparietal diameter (shown in the image) passes through the pelvic brim. Engagement of fetal head is with reference to this biparietal diameter.

It is the greatest transverse diameter in an occiput presentation. It also reflects the gestational age in the second trimester, with a variation of 7-10 days. 

BPD is measured in the transthalamic view, at the level of the thalamus and cavum septum pellucidum (CSP). It is measured from the outer edge of the skull in the near field to the inner edge of the skull in the far field.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with chin protrusion, excessive sweating  as shown in image below and reports that his shoes no longer fit him and his finger ring is getting tightened. Elevated Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels have been observed. Which of the following tests will help to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggest towards the diagnosis of Acromegaly, IGF-1 levels is the screening test and the diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by Oral glucose tolerance test.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. 

Lab Investigations: Age-matched serum IGF-I levels are elevated in acromegaly. Consequently, an IGF-I level provides a useful laboratory screening measure when clinical features raise the possibility of acromegaly. Owing to the pulsatility of GH secretion, measure- ment of a single random GH level is not useful for the diagnosis or exclusion of acromegaly and does not correlate with disease severity.

The diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by demonstrating the failure of GH suppression to <0.4 μg/L within 1–2 h of an oral glucose load (75 g). When newer ultrasensitive GH assays are used, normal nadir GH levels are even lower (<0.05 μg/L). About 20% of patients exhibit a paradoxical GH rise after glucose. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analog), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists or radiation.

 

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: In an immunocompromised patient, which of the following is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of pneumocystis jirovecii?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole combination (commonly known as cotrimoxazole) is the first-line drug for both prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii infections in immunocompromised patients.

Cotrimoxazole acts by causing a sequential block of folate metabolism. CD4+ T cell counts below 200 cells/μL are an indication to start prophylaxis.

questions.text: The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is _____.
questions.solution:
The most common leukemia in children with Down’s syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Note:

  • The most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: is B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL)
  • The most common AML in Down's syndrome: is M7/megakaryoblastic

10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder. These features usually resolve within the 1st 3 months of life. However, they require close follow-up, because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life (AML is more common during the first 3 years of life )

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. On examination, you note tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligaments. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the tender nodularity of the uterosacral ligament points towards a diagnosis of endometriosis.

The nodularity of the uterosacral ligament in endometriosis gives rise to the cobblestone appearance seen on laparoscopy. This is referred to as 'sine qua non of endometriosis'.

The below image shows the cobblestone appearance of the uterosacral ligament.

Note: Endometrioma or chocolate cyst is endometriosis of the ovary. It presents as an adnexal mass.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman consults the doctor for the presence of the skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but now has spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. She has a history of long standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis despite anticoagulation therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image represents necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of long standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

questions.text: Subtype of SCC seen in the below given image is_______
questions.solution:
• The lesion shows an exophytic nodule with central keratinous debris which is a feature of keratoacanthoma.
  • It is a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Option A:
    • Actinic keratoses consist of hyperkeratotic erythematous papules and patches on the sun-exposed skin.
    • They arise in middle-aged to older adults and have some potential for malignant transformation.

Actinic keratoses:

  • Option B:
    • Bowen disease appears histologically as SCC in situ, initially, manifests with a red­dened area that progresses to thickened plaques and may vary from small lesions (<1 cm) to large areas.
    • When it is confined to the glans penis or vulva, Bowen disease is sometimes referred to as Erythroplasia of Queyrat.

Option D: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T cell lymphoma, and plaque-stage lesions are seen.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by TLD badge.

TLD badge (Thermoluminescent dosimeter) is made up of Lithium fluoride or dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices, and the individuals are advised to wear badges at either the waist or the collar level or to wear them either under the lead apron or outside the lead apron.

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favour of delirium?

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.solution:
Fluctuating course is suggestive of delirium.

Characteristic presentation of delirium:

  • Acute onset
  • Brief duration- Usually days to weeks
  • Fluctuating course- Unpredictable fluctuations in severity and other clinical manifestations
  • Sundowning- Worsening of symptoms at night
  • Rapid improvement- When the underlying cause is treated
  • Other charecteristics: Asterexis, Carphologia (Picking movements on cover sheets and clothes)

There is a decline in the level of consciousness.

Delirium is more commonly associated with visual hallucinations.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravidae at 38 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of faintness on lying down for the past one week.  She feels better when she turns to a side and while in sitting position.  What is the reason for her symptoms______
questions.solution:
This is a case of IVC compression known as supine hypotension syndrome (postural hypotension).

  • During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the IVC when the patient is in supine position. In majority of pregnants, to compensate/avoid this effect there will be opening up of collaterals of paravertebral/Azygous veins.
  • When there is failure of opening up of collaterals, venous return of the heart is curtailed leading to hypotension, tachycardia and syncope.
  • The normal BP is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position.Hence pregnant females are adviced to lie in lateral positions (left lateral is better).

questions.text: Ca endometrium involving vagina belongs to _____ stage?
questions.solution:
Stage 3B – Ca endometrium involving vagina &/or parametrium.

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

Stage Tumor extension
Stage I Tumor confined to the corpus uteri
IA No or less than half myometrial Invasion
IB Invasion equal to or more than half of the myometrium
Stage II Tumor invades cervical stroma but does not extend beyond the uterus. Endocervical glandular involvement alone is Stage I
Stage III Local and/or regional spread of the tumor
IIIA Tumor invades the serosa of the corpus uteri and/or adnexa
IIIB Vaginal and/or parametrial involvement
IIIC Metastases to pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes
IIIC1 Positive pelvic nodes
IIIC2 Positive para-aortic lymph nodes with or without positive pelvic lymph nodes
Stage IV Tumor invades bladder and/or bowel mucosa, and/or distant metastases
IVA Tumor invasion of bladder and/or bowel mucosa
IVB Distant metastases, including intra-abdominal metastases and/or inguinal lymph nodes

questions.text: Banana and lemon signs are seen in which of the following fetal anomalies?
questions.solution:
Banana and lemon signs are seen in case of neural tube defects.

Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:

  • Small biparietal diameter
  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign
  • Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna known as banana sign.

questions.text: Tc HMPAO SPECT is used for:
questions.solution:
• Tc HMPAO SPECT is used for cerebral perfusion assessment. For example, in Alzheimer's it shows reduced perfusion of the temporoparietal region.
  • D-SPECT represents the next step in the evolution of SPECT technology and is based on a unique acquisition geometry. It has nine arrays of cadmium zinc telluride (CZT) detectors, each of which rotates around its central axis with programmable angular rotation.

questions.text: A child is brought with fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis. Of the options, meningococcal meningitis is caused by the bacteria Neisseria meningitidis.

CSF findings in different types of meningitis

Parameter/Meningitis Bacterial  Tubercular  Viral 
CSF pressure Raised Raised Raised
Appearance Turbid Clear (cob-web formation) Clear
Glucose Decreased Decreased Normal
Protein High Very high slightly high
Chloride Low Very low Normal
Cells Neutrophils Lymphocytes Lymphocytes

Note:

In partially treated bacterial meningitis, CSF can be clear, with normal glucose levels and lymphocyte predominance. Culture is usually sterile, and antigen can be detected by agglutination test.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not show vertical transmission?
questions.solution:
Tetanus does not show vertical or transplacental transmission.

Transmission of diseases or non-infectious agents transplacentally is called vertical transmission. Diseases that show this type of transmission include:

  • Herpes
  • HIV
  • Rubella
  • Varicella

Apart from diseases, non-infectious agents like lithium, thalidomide, stilbestrol, etc. can cross the placenta and lead to the development of congenital anomalies in a foetus.

Note: Neonatal tetanus occurs as a result of the failure to use aseptic techniques in managing the umbilical stump, unclean hands, and instruments or contamination by dirt, straw, or other nonsterile materials in the delivery field. Immunisation of pregnant women can prevent this disease via the transplacental transport of immunoglobulins.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a double-barrelled aorta seen?
questions.solution:
A double-barrelled aorta is seen in an aortic dissection.

An aortic dissection usually initiates with an intimal tear. In some instances, the dissecting hematoma reenters the lumen of the aorta through a second distal intimal tear, creating a new vascular channel and forming a double-barreled aorta with a false channel.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on location of proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system that uses location of proximal tear alone. 

DeBakey system:

  • Type I: involves the ascending aorta and extends through the aortic arch and into the descending aorta/abdominal aorta
  • Type II: confined to the ascending aorta
  • Type IIIa: limited to the descending aorta
  • Type IIIb: descending aorta and abdominal aorta

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema involving the upper limb.

Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly.

Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility.

Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.

Management:

Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce swelling. 

Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful.

Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.

Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat lymphedema.

Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking.

Other options:

Option B:   Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.

Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painful swelling of the arm is observed.

Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.

questions.text:
An intern posted in the labour room is administering birth dose vaccines to a newborn baby. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which of the following vaccines would he not administer?
  1. OPV
  2. IPV
  3. BCG
  4. Hepatitis B
  5. Pentavalent
questions.solution:
Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) and pentavalent vaccine are not given at birth. The vaccines given at birth are BCG, OPV (0 dose) and hepatitis B vaccines.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the clinic as he appears to turn blue every time he cries. Chest x-ray reveals the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows an enlarged, box-shaped cardiac silhouette, that is typically seen in Ebstein's anomaly. 

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by an abnormal tricuspid valve that is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis.

X-ray findings depend on the degree to which the tricuspid valve is displaced downwards. The following features may be seen:

  • Enlarged right atrium - causes severe right-sided cardiomegaly
  • Pulmonary oligemia

questions.text: The peripheries will be warm and capillary refill will be brisk in which of the following types of shock?
questions.solution: In distributive shock (eg: sepsis, anaphylaxis, high spinal cord injury), the periphery will be warm and capillary refill will be brisk due to low peripheral vascular resistance (vasodilation).

questions.text: Identify the type of ataxia given below -
questions.solution:
The gait shown in the above video is a cerebellar ataxic gait.

Cerebellar gait ataxia is characterized by a wide base of support, lateral instability of the trunk, and erratic foot placement. There is a loss of balance when attempting to walk on a narrow base. Difficulty maintaining balance when turning is often an early feature. They show considerable variation in their tendency to fall in daily life.

Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displays improper heel-toe coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying.

Causes of cerebellar ataxia include stroke, trauma, tumor, hereditary cerebellar degeneration, Wilson's disease, neurodegenerative disorders like multiple-system atrophy (MSA). Alcohol causes both acute and chronic cerebellar ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with sensory ataxia walk unsteadily with multiple falls, on a narrow base, and tend to look down while walking. They lose balance on walking with their eyes closed or in the dark. Joint sense and vibration sense are diminished. Dorsal column lesions of the spinal cord result in sensory ataxia. 

Option C: Frontal ataxia or shuffling, freezing gait includes a wide base of support, a short stride, shuffling along the floor, and difficulty with starts and turns. Many patients exhibit difficulty with gait initiation which is descriptively characterized as the “slipping clutch” syndrome or gait ignition failure. It is commonly seen in the elderly.

Option D: Spastic gait is characterized by stiffness in the legs, and a tendency to circumduct and scuff the feet. It is associated with an imbalance in muscle tone. Lesions in the corticospinal tract result in spastic gait.

questions.text: All of the following forms the right cardiac border on Chest X-ray PA view except:
questions.solution:
Right cardiac border formed by:

  • SVC
  • Right atrium
  • IVC

Left cardiac border formed by:

  • Subclavian artery
  • Aortic knuckle
  • Pulmonary artery segment
  • Left atrial appendage
  • Left ventricle

questions.text: A pregnant woman with fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain in abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/ul.  The most likely diagnosis is____________
questions.solution:
In this case, there is a severe acute pain abdomen without fever and normal leukocyte count in a 28-week pregnant woman with fibroid. Hence the most likely diagnosis is torsion of fibroid.

Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen but fever and leukocytosis are absent.

Red degeneration of fibroid presents with acute pain abdomen, vomiting, leukocytosis and raised ESR.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to the OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score.
questions.solution:
The obstetric score of the patient is G4 P1 A2 L1. 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
  • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages.
  • L - Living children

Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins will be expressed as primipara.

The GTPAL system includes the following:

  • Gravida
  • Term (>37 weeks)
  • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
  • Abortions (<20 weeks)
  • Number of living children

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with pigmentation of the lips and oral mucosa and intestinal polyps. The most probable diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
Peutz–Jeghers syndrome is characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract (more commonly small intestine) and hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits.

Turcot syndrome: It constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumours (including cerebellar medulloblastoma and glioblastomas)

Lynch syndrome: It is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due to defective mismatch repair (MMR) of DNA.

Cowden disease: It is characterised by polyps of stomach or colon with mucocutaneous lesions, thyroid adenomas and goitre, fibroadenomas and fibrocystic disease of the breast, Uterine leiomyomas, macrocephaly.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract, with cancers reported throughout the intestinal tract, from the stomach to the rectum.
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation. Which of the following organs is likely to be affected the most?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the ovary is most likely to be affected as it is the most radiosensitive organ. 

Radiosensitivity of pelvic organs is as follows: ovary>rectum>bladder>vagina. Radiation tolerance dose for ovary is 2-3 Gy whereas vagina 90 Gy. Hence, among the given options, the vagina is the most radioresistant organ.

The radiation dose necessary to induce ovarian failure is age-dependent. A single dose of 3-4 Gray can induce amenorrhea in almost all women >40 yrs of age. In young women, oogenesis is much less sensitive to radiation as compared to the elderly. 

Radiosensitivity of various tissues is summed up in the table given below: 

  Most radiosensitive Least radiosensitive
Tissue Bone marrow, Gonads Nervous tissue, Muscle fibers
Blood cells Lymphocytes Platelets
Stages of cell cycle G2M interphase S phase
Cell types Rapidly dividing Quiescent
Ocular structure Lens Sclera
Layer of retina Rods Ganglion cell layer

The skin is most commonly affected due to radiation. Stratum basalis is the layer of the skin most affected.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Which of the following best describes the microscopic finding given below?

choices.text: Epithelial cell with bacteria attached on cell surface

questions.solution:
The microscopic finding is epithelial cells, with bacteria attached to them called as clue cells.

Clue cells are the most reliable indicators of Bacterial Vaginosis. These vaginal epithelial cells contain many attached bacteria, which create a poorly defined stippled border. At least 20 percent of the epithelial cells should be clue cells in a Wet Mount preparation to be diagnostic of bacterial vaginosis. The presence of clue cells is one of the 4 criteria described in Amsel’s criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma is not a characteristic feature of the symptom complex of MEN2 and its variants, but it is observed in MEN1 and MEN4 syndrome.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: You are an intern examining a 68-year-old male patient who is a known case of rheumatic heart disease. You are able to feel a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. What is the type of pulse?
questions.solution:
A 68-year-old male patient who is a known case of rheumatic heart disease with a bifid pulse is suggestive of aortic regurgitation and the type of pulse is Pulsus bisferiens. It is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR)
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Water hummer or Corrigan's pulse (option A) is one which collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls during late systole and diastole. Quincke's pulse (option B) is seen when pressure is applied at the tip of the nail. It causes alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail. These pulses can be seen in aortic regurgitation.

Pulsus paradoxus (option D) is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, massive pulmonary embolism, haemorrhagic shock, obstructive lung disease and tension pneumothorax. It is characterised by a fall in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration.

The below image shows different arterial pressure waves

questions.text: Which of the following is false about giant cell arteritis?
questions.solution:
Giant cell arteritis is common in females older than 50 year of age.

Giant cell arteritis is an inflammatory vasculitis of the large vessels. It usually involves the temporal artery.

Common clinical features associated with giant cell arteritis are:

  • It is commonly seen in females over 50 years of age.
  • It is characterised by fever, anemia and headache.
  • Depending on the artery involved, the patient may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, jaw and tongue claudication.
  • Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR, normochromic normocytic anemia.
  • Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy.
  • Good response to glucocorticoid therapy.

questions.text: When performing the test on a patient as shown in the image, you noticed that there was tenderness and resistance on flexion. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
The given findings can be seen in a patient with DVT and this is known as Homan’s sign i.e. calf tenderness and resistance on forced ankle dorsiflexion.

Moses Sign - calf tenderness on direct pressure on the calf.

Pratt’s Sign - calf tenderness on squeezing the calf from sides.

Lowenberg’s sign- pain when blood pressure cuff placed on the calf is inflated to 80 mm of Hg

questions.text: Below is the chest X-ray image obtained for a neonate on day 7 of life who developed heart failure later​. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic "egg on end" appearance on this chest X-ray image is seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). 

In the chest X-ray image, cardiomegaly with narrow mediastinum gives rise to the classic “egg-shaped heart.” The superior mediastinum appears narrow due to the anteroposterior relationship of the transposed great vessels and radiologic-absence of the thymus.

Note:

  • TGA is the most specific heart disease in the infant of a diabetic mother.
  • TGA is associated with uncontrolled phenylketonuria (PKU) in mother.

questions.text: Which of the following foods will you recommend to a patient to reduce symptoms of GERD?
questions.solution:
Protein increases the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure, thereby allowing the closure of the sphincter and reducing reflux. Coffee, fatty foods, and peppermint decrease the LES pressure.

Option A: Chocolate and coffee both contain methylxanthine, which causes muscles to relax and lowers the LES pressure. In addition, coffee can stimulate gastric secretions, which can promote reflux. 

Option B: Fatty foods have been found to delay gastric emptying and decrease the LES pressure, thereby prolonging the esophageal exposure time to the stomach acid and the volume available for reflux.

Option D: Alcohol, mint, citrus, tomatoes, and/or carbonated beverages may cause further irritation to the damaged esophageal mucosa but have not been found to cause reflux themselves.
